1.summary:
The Reliant Care 3 plan offers a structured set of benefits focusing on primary and specialist care, hospitalization, telemedicine, and prescription services. Members are entitled to four primary care office visits per year with a $25 co-pay and a maximum of $150 per visit. Specialist or urgent care visits are also limited to four per year, with a $50 co-pay and a $300 maximum per visit. In-patient hospitalization benefits are provided at $1,000 per day, with a yearly maximum of $15,000, subject to a 12-month pre-existing condition exclusion period.

Telemedicine services are available with no consult fee and no maximum usage limit, enhancing accessibility to healthcare professionals. The prescription plan includes preventive and acute prescriptions, with generic drugs available at no co-pay for a 30-day supply. Preferred generics incur a $5 co-pay, while non-preferred generics and brand drugs require member payment, with specific costs for retail and mail-order options.

The plan includes a 30-day waiting period for sickness benefits and requires the use of in-network providers for outpatient services. Hospitalization benefits are not payable for pre-existing conditions within the first 12 months. The plan does not cover services outside the listed benefits, emphasizing the importance of reviewing the schedule of benefits for exclusions and limitations.

4.summary:
This page outlines the preventative health services covered under the MEC plan, detailing the benefits, intervals, and specific requirements for each service. Gonorrhea prophylactic medication is provided as prescribed for all newborns to prevent gonococcal ophthalmia neonatorum. Gonorrhea screening is available once per plan year for sexually active women aged 24 years or younger and older women at increased risk. Healthy diet and physical activity counseling is offered once per plan year for adults who are overweight or obese with cardiovascular disease risk factors. Hemoglobinopathies screening is conducted once per plan year for sickle cell disease in newborns.

Hepatitis B and C screenings are available once per plan year for non-pregnant adolescents and adults at high risk, and for adults born between 1945 and 1965, respectively. High blood pressure screening is provided once per plan year for adults aged 18 or older. HIV preexposure prophylaxis is prescribed for individuals at high risk of HIV acquisition, while HIV screening is available once per plan year for adolescents and adults aged 15 to 65 years, and for pregnant women. Hypothyroidism screening is conducted once per plan year for newborns.

Intimate partner violence screening is available once per plan year for women of reproductive age. Lung cancer screening is offered once per plan year for adults aged 55 to 80 years with a significant smoking history. Obesity screening and counseling are provided once per plan year for children and adolescents aged 6 years and older. Osteoporosis screening is available once per plan year for women aged 65 and older. Phenylketonuria screening is conducted once per plan year for newborns.

2.summary:
This document outlines the preventive health services covered under the MEC/Preventative Health Services plan. Benefits are automatically subject to specific federal regulations, and any amendments are incorporated by reference. The preventive services include medical services rated 'A' or 'B' by the United States Preventive Services Task Force, preventive care for infants, children, and adolescents, and immunizations recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices.

The benefits include various screenings and counseling services. Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Screening is available once per lifetime for men aged 65-75 who have smoked. Adult Annual Standard Physical is provided once per plan year for adults. Alcohol Misuse Screening and Counseling is available once per plan year for adults 18 and older. Aspirin is prescribed for adults aged 50-59 at risk of cardiovascular diseases. Bacteriuria Screening is available once per plan year for pregnant women. BRCA Risk Assessment and Genetic Counseling/Testing is offered once per plan year for women with a family history of certain cancers. Breast Cancer Preventive Medications are prescribed for women at increased risk. Breast Cancer Screening is available once every two years for women aged 50 and older.

These services are not covered if provided at a hospital, emphasizing the plan's focus on preventive care in non-hospital settings.

5.summary:
This document outlines the preventive health services covered under the MEC plan, detailing the benefits, intervals, and specific requirements for each service. Preeclampsia screening is available once per plan year for pregnant women, focusing on blood pressure measurements throughout pregnancy. Rh incompatibility screening is provided during the first pregnancy visit and again at 24-28 weeks' gestation for unsensitized Rh (D)-negative women, unless the biological father is known to be Rh (D)-negative.

Sexually transmitted infections counseling is offered once per plan year for sexually active adolescents and adults at increased risk. Skin cancer behavioral counseling is available for young individuals and children to minimize ultraviolet exposure. Statin preventive medication is prescribed for adults without a history of cardiovascular disease but with risk factors such as dyslipidemia or hypertension.

Syphilis screening is provided annually for non-pregnant persons at risk and all pregnant women. Tobacco use counseling and interventions are covered twice per plan year, including behavioral interventions and FDA-approved pharmacotherapy. Tuberculosis screening is available annually for at-risk populations. Vision screening is offered once every two plan years for children aged 3 to 5. Well-woman visits and well-child visits are covered annually, focusing on age-appropriate preventive services and prenatal care.

3.summary:
This page provides a detailed summary of preventative health services covered under the MEC plan. It outlines various benefits, intervals, and specific requirements for each service. Breastfeeding support, supplies, and counseling are provided in conjunction with each birth, with interventions during pregnancy and after birth to support breastfeeding. Cervical cancer screening with cytology is available once every three years for women aged 21 to 65, while screening with a combination of cytology and HPV testing is available once every five years for women aged 30 to 65. Chlamydia screening is offered annually for sexually active women aged 24 and younger, as well as older women at increased risk of infection.

Colorectal cancer screening is provided once every five years for adults aged 50 to 75, with benefits for a colonoscopy if initial screening is positive. Contraceptive methods and counseling are covered as prescribed, excluding abortifacient drugs. Dental caries prevention for infants and children up to age 5 includes fluoride varnish application and oral fluoride supplementation starting at age 6 months. Depression screening is available annually for the general adult population, including pregnant and postpartum women, with a focus on accurate diagnosis and follow-up.

Diabetes screening is offered annually for adults aged 40 to 70 who are overweight or obese, with counseling interventions for those with abnormal blood glucose. Fall prevention for older adults includes exercise interventions for those aged 65 and older. Folic acid supplementation is covered as prescribed for women planning a pregnancy. Gestational diabetes mellitus screening is available for asymptomatic pregnant women after 24 weeks of gestation.

7.summary:
This page provides a detailed summary of benefits for the MEC/Preventative Health Services plan, focusing on immunizations for adults aged nineteen years or older. The immunizations covered include Influenza (IIV, RIV, LAIV), Tdap, MMR, Varicella, RZV, ZVL, HPV for both females and males, PCV13, and PPSV23. Each vaccine has specific age requirements and limitations, such as annual doses or age-specific recommendations. For example, the Influenza inactivated vaccine is recommended annually for ages 19 to 65, while the Tdap vaccine is advised every ten years for the same age group.

The page also outlines exclusions applicable to the benefits offered under this plan. These exclusions include office visits for physical exams related to sports, employment, or travel, and routine foot care for conditions like flat feet and corns. Other exclusions cover cosmetic surgery unless deemed medically necessary, and any treatment related to teeth or periodontium unless specified in the schedule of benefits. Additionally, claims related to injuries from employment or those covered by a Worker’s Compensation policy are excluded.

The document emphasizes that any medical service, treatment, or procedure not explicitly covered under this plan is excluded, along with any associated expenses. This includes services not provided by the plan document or its appendices.

6.summary:
This page provides a detailed summary of immunization benefits under the MEC/Preventative Health Services plan. It outlines the recommended vaccines for children and adolescents as advised by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The document is divided into two sections based on age groups: Birth through Six Years Old and Children from Seven through Eighteen Years Old.

For the Birth through Six Years Old category, the vaccines listed include Hepatitis B, Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Acellular Pertussis (DTap), Haemophilus Influenzae Type B (Hib), Pneumococcal 13-valent Conjugate (PCV13), Inactivated Poliovirus (IPV), Influenza (yearly), Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR), Varicella, Hepatitis A, and Rotavirus. Each vaccine has specific age requirements and limitations, such as the age range for administration and the number of doses required.

For Children from Seven through Eighteen Years Old, the vaccines include Influenza (yearly), Tetanus, Diphtheria, and Acellular Pertussis (Tdap), Human Papillomavirus (HPV), and Meningococcal Serogroups A, C, W, Y (MenACWY). The document specifies the recommended ages for each vaccine and any special notes, such as the need for a 3-shot series of the HPV vaccine for certain individuals.

8.summary:
This page outlines the exclusions and limitations associated with the MEC/Preventative Health Services plan. It specifies that claims arising from service outside the United States are not covered, except for certain claims billed by the Veterans Administration or Department of Defense. Claims for services not deemed medically necessary by the plan, or those exceeding customary rates without a PPO network contract, are excluded. Additionally, charges reimbursed by public health programs are not covered. 

The document lists specific exclusions such as claims due to acts of war, terrorism, or illegal acts, and those related to investigatory or experimental treatments. Claims for weight control, infertility treatment, and cosmetic surgery not related to mastectomy reconstruction are also excluded. The plan does not cover services like acupuncture, chiropractic care, and alternative medicine. 

Furthermore, the plan excludes claims for personal convenience items, recreational therapy, and non-emergency care outside the U.S. It also specifies that routine care for newborns while inpatient and pregnancy-related services are not covered. The purpose of this list is to clarify treatments and services not included under the plan, emphasizing that exclusions should not imply coverage.

9.summary: This cover page introduces the Reliant Care Health Insurance Plans, featuring a total of six distinct plans. The plans listed include Reliant Care Wellness, Reliant Care 1, Reliant Care 2, Reliant Care 3, Reliant Care 4, and Reliant Care 5. The page prominently displays the Reliant Care logo, emphasizing the brand identity. This introductory page serves as a gateway to detailed information about each plan, setting the stage for further exploration of the benefits and features offered by Reliant Care. The page is designed to provide a clear and concise overview of the available plans, ensuring that potential customers are aware of the options they can explore.

11.summary:
The Reliant Care 1 plan offers a structured set of benefits focusing on physician services, telemedicine, and advocacy. Under physician services, the plan allows for three primary care office visits per year with a co-pay of $25 and a maximum charge of $150 per visit. Specialist or urgent care office visits are limited to one per year, with a $50 co-pay and a $300 maximum per visit. In-patient hospitalization benefits are provided at $1,000 per day, with a yearly maximum of $5,000, subject to a 12-month pre-existing condition exclusion.

Telemedicine services are offered with no consult fee and no maximum limit, enhancing accessibility to healthcare professionals. The plan also includes a discount prescription program available at participating pharmacies. Advocacy services are provided through a hospital bill reducer program, assisting members in managing healthcare expenses.

The plan has specific limitations, including a 30-day waiting period for sickness benefits and restrictions to in-network providers for outpatient services. Hospitalization benefits are not payable for pre-existing conditions within the first 12 months of coverage. The plan does not cover services outside the listed benefits, emphasizing the need to review the schedule of benefits for detailed coverage information.

12.summary:
The Reliant Care 2 plan offers a range of healthcare services with specific visit limits and copay structures. For physician services, the plan allows for four primary care office visits per year with a $25 copay and a maximum charge of $150 per visit. Specialist or urgent care visits are limited to two per year, with a $50 copay and a $300 maximum per visit. In-patient hospitalization benefits provide $1,000 per day, capped at $10,000 annually, with a 12-month pre-existing condition exclusion period.

Telemedicine services are available with no consult fee and no maximum limit, enhancing accessibility to healthcare professionals. The plan includes a prescription component, covering preventative and acute prescriptions subject to a formulary. Pharmacy retail for up to a 30-day supply requires member payment, with generic drugs having a $0 copay. For a 90-day supply of 200 generic maintenance drugs via mail order, the preferred generic copay is $5.

The plan includes several limitations and exclusions. All sickness benefits are subject to a 30-day waiting period. Outpatient services must be in-network, and hospitalization benefits are not payable for pre-existing conditions within the first 12 months. Specialty drugs are excluded, but a Prescription Assistance Program is available. The plan emphasizes preventive and wellness services as mandated by the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.

10.summary:
The Reliant Care Wellness plan offers specific benefits focused on wellness exams and telemedicine services. Under the Physician Services section, utilizing the First Health Network, the plan provides one wellness exam per year with a co-pay of $25 and a maximum coverage of $150 per visit. Telemedicine services are available through Kindly Human and Recuro Health, with a $0 consult fee and no maximum limit on visits. Additionally, the plan includes discount prescriptions available only at participating pharmacies.

The plan is sponsored by The Vitamin Patch and administered by Merchants Benefit Admin, with network services provided by First Health Network. It is important to note that all sickness benefits are subject to a 30-day waiting period before they become payable. Outpatient physician services and wellness benefits are restricted to in-network providers only. The plan is limited to preventive and wellness services as required by the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, and does not cover services unless listed in the Schedule of Benefits.

The document emphasizes the importance of reviewing the Schedule of Benefits for a detailed understanding of covered services, copays, deductibles, and limitations. This ensures that members are aware of the specific terms and conditions associated with their coverage.

16.summary:
This document outlines the preventive health services covered under the MEC/Preventative Health Services plan. Benefits are automatically subject to 29 CFR § 2590.715-2713(a), with amendments incorporated through legislative acts or regulations. The preventive services include medical services rated 'A' or 'B' by the United States Preventive Services Task Force, preventive care for infants, children, and adolescents, and immunizations recommended by the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. 

The benefits include various screenings and preventive medications. Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Screening is available once per lifetime for men aged 65-75 who have smoked. Adult Annual Standard Physical is covered once per plan year for adults. Alcohol misuse screening and counseling are provided annually for adults 18 years or older. Aspirin is prescribed for adults aged 50 to 59 at high risk of cardiovascular diseases. Bacteriuria Screening is available once per plan year for pregnant women. BRCA Risk Assessment and Genetic Counseling/Testing are covered annually for women with a family history of certain cancers. Breast Cancer Preventive Medications are prescribed for women at increased risk. Breast Cancer Screening is available once every two years for women aged 50 and older, limited to 2D mammograms.

It is important to note that none of these preventive health services are covered if provided at a hospital.

14.summary:
The Reliant Care 4 plan offers a range of benefits focusing on physician services, hospitalization, surgery, and prescriptions. Under physician services, the plan includes one wellness exam per year with a $25 co-pay and a maximum of $150 per visit. Primary care office visits are covered for up to four visits per year with a $50 co-pay, while specialist or urgent care visits have a $75 co-pay with a $300 maximum per visit. In-patient hospitalization benefits provide $1,000 per day with a $10,000 annual maximum, subject to a 12-month pre-existing condition clause. In/outpatient surgery is covered at $1,000 per year with a $2,000 annual maximum, also subject to a 12-month pre-existing condition clause. Emergency room visits and ambulance services are covered at $1,000 and $500 per incident, respectively, with similar pre-existing condition limitations.

Telemedicine services are available with no consultation fee and no maximum limit. Prescription benefits include a pharmacy retail option for up to a 30-day supply of acute and preventive generic drugs, with member payments required. Generic drugs have a $0 co-pay, while preferred generics have a $5 co-pay. Non-preferred generics and brand drugs require member payments, with specific co-pays for mail orders. The plan includes a prescription assistance program for non-preventive maintenance prescriptions, with certain specialty drugs not covered.

The plan has specific terms and conditions, including a 30-day waiting period for sickness benefits and in-network provider requirements for outpatient services. Hospitalization benefits are not payable for pre-existing conditions within the first 12 months. The plan does not cover services unless listed in the Schedule of Benefits, emphasizing the importance of reviewing the list carefully.

15.summary:
The Reliant Care 5 plan offers a range of healthcare services with specific visit limits and co-pay amounts. For physician services, the plan includes one wellness exam per year with a $25 co-pay and a maximum of $150 per visit. Primary care office visits are limited to five per year, each with a $50 co-pay and a $150 maximum. Specialist or urgent care office visits also have a limit of five per year, with a $75 co-pay and a $300 maximum per visit. In-patient hospitalization benefits are provided at $1,500 per day, with a yearly maximum of $15,000, subject to a 12-month pre-existing condition clause. In/outpatient surgery is covered up to $4,500 per year, also with a 12-month pre-existing condition clause. Emergency room visits, if admitted, incur a $1,000 charge per incident, and ambulance services are $500 per incident, both subject to the same pre-existing condition clause.

Telemedicine services are available with no consult fee and no maximum limit. The plan includes pharmacy benefits for a 30-day supply of acute and preventive generic drugs, with member payments required. Preferred generics have a $5 co-pay, while non-preferred generics have a $10 co-pay for a 30-day supply and a $20 co-pay for a 90-day mail order. Brand drugs require prior authorization, with specific co-pays for retail and mail orders. Prescription terms specify that non-preventive maintenance prescriptions are subject to a $150 monthly benefit limit per person, and specialty drugs are not covered.

The plan includes a 30-day waiting period for sickness benefits and requires in-network providers for outpatient physician services and wellness benefits. Hospitalization benefits are not payable for pre-existing conditions within the first 12 months. The plan does not cover services unless listed in the Schedule of Benefits, and it is limited to preventive and wellness services as per the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act.

20.summary:

For children from birth through six years old, the plan covers vaccines such as Hepatitis B, Diphtheria, Tetanus, and Acellular Pertussis (DTap), Haemophilus Influenzae Type B (Hib), Pneumococcal 13-valent Conjugate (PCV13), Inactivated Poliovirus (IPV), Influenza (yearly), Measles, Mumps, and Rubella (MMR), Varicella, Hepatitis A, and Rotavirus. Other screenings include Hypothyroidism Screening for newborns, Intimate Partner Violence Screening for women of reproductive age, and Lung Cancer Screening for adults aged 55 to 80 years with a significant smoking history. Obesity Screening and Counseling is provided for children and adolescents aged 6 years and older, and adults with a BMI of 30 kg/m2 or higher. Osteoporosis Screening is available for women aged 65 and older, and younger postmenopausal women at increased risk. Phenylketonuria Screening is conducted for newborns.

53.summary:
This page outlines the exclusions and limitations associated with the MEC/Preventative Health Services plan. It specifies that claims arising from service outside the United States are not covered, except for certain claims billed by the Veterans Administration or Department of Defense. Claims for services not deemed medically necessary or those exceeding customary rates are excluded. The plan does not cover charges reimbursed by public health programs or claims due to acts of war or terrorism. Additionally, services related to investigatory or experimental treatments, weight control, and cosmetic surgery are not covered unless specified in the schedule of benefits.

The document lists specific exclusions such as claims for eyeglasses, contacts, hearing aids, and abortion services unless specified. It also excludes custodial care, services from non-healthcare providers, and claims related to self-inflicted injuries or illegal acts. Claims for infertility treatment, sterilization reversal, and recreational therapy are not covered. The plan excludes treatments for sexual dysfunction, biofeedback training, and skilled nursing facilities unless explicitly covered.

Further exclusions include chiropractic care, acupuncture, alternative medicine, and certain dental and vision services. The plan does not cover non-emergency care outside the U.S., pregnancy benefits, or routine well-baby care while inpatient. The purpose of these exclusions is to clarify treatments and services not covered under this plan, ensuring no implication of coverage where it does not exist.

BRCA Risk Assessment and Genetic Counseling/Testing

Screening to women who have family members with breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer with one of several screening tools designed to identify a family history that may be associated with an increased risk for potentially harmful mutations in breast cancer susceptibility genes (BRCA1 or BRCA2). Women with positive screening results should receive genetic counseling and, if indicated after counseling, BRCA testing.
Risk-reducing medications, such as tamoxifen, raloxifene, or aromatase inhibitors for women who are at increased risk for breast cancer and at low risk for adverse medication effects.
Screening mammography for women age 50 years and older. Coverage limited to 2D mammograms only.

Screening for intimate partner violence, in women of reproductive age and provide or refer women who screen positive to ongoing support services.

With low-dose computed tomography in adults aged 55 to 80 years who have a 30 pack-year smoking history and currently smoke or have quit within the past 15 years. Screening should be discontinued once a person has not smoked for 15 years or develops a health problem that substantially limits life expectancy or the ability or willingness to have curative lung surgery.

To children and adolescents 6 years and older and offer or refer them to comprehensive, intensive behavioral interventions to promote improvements in weight status. Screening all adults. Clinicians should offer or refer patients with a body mass index of 30 kg/m2 or higher to intensive, multicomponent behavioral interventions.
In women aged 65 and older and in younger postmenopausal women at increased risk of osteoporosis.
By ultrasonography in men ages 65-75 years who have ever smoked
Adults, one (1) physical preventive exam per plan year.
Alcohol Misuse: Unhealthy Alcohol Use Screening and Counseling

Screenings for unhealthy alcohol use in adults 18 years or older, including pregnant women, and providing persons engaged in risky or hazardous drinking with brief behavioral counseling interventions to reduce unhealthy alcohol use.

Adults age 50 to 59 with high risk of cardiovascular diseases and for the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease and colorectal cancer. Low-dose aspirin (81 mg/d) as preventive medication for women after 12 weeks of gestation who are at high risk for pre-eclampsia.
Screening for asymptomatic bacteriuria with urine culture in pregnant women at 12 to 16 weeks’ gestation or at the first prenatal visit, if later.
BRCA Risk Assessment and Genetic Counseling/Testing

Screening to women who have family members with breast, ovarian, tubal, or peritoneal cancer with one of several screening tools designed to identify a family history that may be associated with an increased risk for potentially harmful mutations in breast cancer susceptibility genes (BRCA1 or BRCA2). Women with positive screening results should receive genetic counseling and, if indicated after counseling, BRCA testing.
Risk-reducing medications, such as tamoxifen, raloxifene, or aromatase inhibitors for women who are at increased risk for breast cancer and at low risk for adverse medication effects.
Screening mammography for women age 50 years and older. Coverage limited to 2D mammograms only.

presentation.content:
# Deck ID: FEN_RLC
# Deck Title: Reliant Care

## Cover
- **Plan Name:** Reliant Care
- **Tagline:** Comprehensive Healthcare Solutions for Every Need

## Plan Overview
- **Target Audience:** Individuals and Families
- **Offerings:** Healthcare, Affordability
- **Key Benefits:** Accessibility, Personal Impact

## Core Plan Elements
### Slide 1
- **Coverage Areas:** Physician Services, Hospitalization, Virtual Visits
- **Plan Structure:** Tiered Options, Co-pays, Visit Limits
- **Eligibility:** Individuals, Families, Affordability Focus

### Slide 2
- **Coverage Details:** 
  - Physician Services: Primary and Specialist Care
  - Hospitalization: In-patient and Out-patient
  - Virtual Visits: Unlimited Access

## Common Service Features
### Slide 1
- **Provider Networks:** First Health Network
- **Claims Management:** Efficient and User-Friendly
- **Support Tools:** Dashboards, Wellness Programs

### Slide 2
- **Advocacy Services:** Hospital Bill Reducer
- **Wellness Programs:** Preventive Care Focus

## Plan Tiers Breakdown

### Reliant Care Wellness
- **Physician Services:** 1 Wellness Exam/yr, $25 Co-pay, $150 Max/Visit
- **Telemedicine:** No Consult Fee, No Maximum
- **Prescriptions:** Discount at Participating Pharmacies

### Reliant Care 1
- **Physician Services:** 3 Primary Care Visits/yr, $25 Co-pay, $150 Max/Visit
- **Hospitalization:** $1,000/Day, $5,000/Year Max
- **Telemedicine:** No Consult Fee, No Maximum
- **Advocacy:** Hospital Bill Reducer

### Reliant Care 2
- **Physician Services:** 4 Primary Care Visits/yr, $25 Co-pay, $150 Max/Visit
- **Hospitalization:** $1,000/Day, $10,000/Year Max
- **Telemedicine:** No Consult Fee, No Maximum
- **Prescriptions:** Generic $0 Co-pay, Preferred Generic $5 Co-pay

### Reliant Care 3
- **Physician Services:** 4 Primary Care Visits/yr, $25 Co-pay, $150 Max/Visit
- **Hospitalization:** $1,000/Day, $15,000/Year Max
- **Telemedicine:** No Consult Fee, No Maximum
- **Prescriptions:** Generic $0 Co-pay, Preferred Generic $5 Co-pay

### Reliant Care 4
- **Physician Services:** 4 Primary Care Visits/yr, $50 Co-pay, $150 Max/Visit
- **Hospitalization:** $1,000/Day, $10,000/Year Max
- **Surgery:** $1,000/Year, $2,000/Year Max
- **Telemedicine:** No Consult Fee, No Maximum

### Reliant Care 5
- **Physician Services:** 5 Primary Care Visits/yr, $50 Co-pay, $150 Max/Visit
- **Hospitalization:** $1,500/Day, $15,000/Year Max
- **Surgery:** $1,500/Year, $4,500/Year Max
- **Telemedicine:** No Consult Fee, No Maximum

## Comparison Slides
| Feature                  | Wellness | Care 1 | Care 2 | Care 3 | Care 4 | Care 5 |
|--------------------------|----------|--------|--------|--------|--------|--------|
| Primary Care Visits/yr   | 1        | 3      | 4      | 4      | 4      | 5      |
| Specialist Visits/yr     | -        | 1      | 2      | 4      | 4      | 5      |
| Hospitalization/Day      | -        | $1,000 | $1,000 | $1,000 | $1,000 | $1,500 |
| Yearly Hospital Max      | -        | $5,000 | $10,000| $15,000| $10,000| $15,000|
| Telemedicine             | Yes      | Yes    | Yes    | Yes    | Yes    | Yes    |
| Prescription Co-pay      | Discount | Discount| $0/$5 | $0/$5 | $0/$5 | $0/$5 |

## Limitations and Exclusions
- **Exclusions:** Pre-existing Conditions, Waiting Periods, Prescription Limitations
- **Specific Limitations:** Specialty Drugs Excluded, In-network Provider Requirement

## Key Takeaways and Action Steps
- **Flexibility:** Multiple Tiers for Diverse Needs
- **Cost vs. Coverage:** Balanced Options
- **Next Steps:** Enrollment Support Available

## Thank You
- **Message:** Thank you for considering Reliant Care for your healthcare needs.

script.content:
---- Cover ----

Hello, everyone! Thank you for joining today's session on the Reliant Care Health Insurance Plans. We'll walk through the details and benefits of these plans, designed to provide accessible healthcare solutions for your members. Let's dive right in!

---- Plan Overview ----

The Reliant Care Plan

offers healthcare solutions through the First Health Network, 

providing Physician Services for both primary and specialist care. 

It includes Hospitalization and telemedicine support, 

with Prescription Benefits available through participating pharmacies. 

Additionally, Advocacy Services are provided to support members.

---- Key Features and Benefits ----

Let's explore the key features and benefits of this plan.

The plan emphasizes Healthcare Accessibility, 

with a strong focus on Affordability. 

It offers broad Coverage that varies by plan, 

and includes Telemedicine Services through Kindly Human and Recuro Health.

---- Cost Management Tools ----

Now, let's discuss the cost management tools available with this plan.

The Hospital Bill Reducer, or HBR, 

is a key feature, along with an Efficient Claims Management System. 

Members also have access to Support Tools and dashboards.

---- How Hospital Bill Reducer Works ----

Here's how the Hospital Bill Reducer works.

First, members enroll through the First Health Network. 

They then submit hospital bills for review. 

The advocacy team negotiates on their behalf, 

resulting in a reduced bill statement through HBR. 

Finally, members pay the reduced amount.

---- Preventive Care and Wellness ----

Preventive Care and Wellness are integral parts of the plan.

Members have access to Annual Physical Exams Services, 

as well as Wellness Programs and screenings. 

The First Health Network ensures a wide range of care options.

---- Telehealth Services ----

Let's talk about Telehealth Services.

Members enjoy Unlimited Access to virtual visits, 

with No Consult Fee for telemedicine services. 

These services are available 24/7 for consultations, 

providing Convenient Access to care.

---- Advocacy and Support Services ----

Advocacy and Support Services are crucial for member assistance.

Members receive Personalized healthcare advocacy, 

including Hospital Bill Reducer assistance. 

There are also Claims Management options, 

and Support Tools available for members.

---- Plan Tier 1 (One of Two) ----

Let's examine our first plan tier, Reliant Care Wellness.

Physician Services include one Wellness Exam per year, 

with a twenty-five dollar Co-pay and a one hundred fifty dollar maximum per visit. 

Telemedicine services have No Consult Fee and No Maximum. 

Prescriptions offer a Discount at Participating Pharmacies.

---- Plan Tier 1 (Two of Two) ----

Continuing with our first plan tier.

Advocacy Services include the Hospital Bill Reducer. 

There are Limitations, such as a thirty-day waiting period for sickness benefits, 

and an in-network provider requirement.

---- Plan Tier 2 (One of Two) ----

Now, let's look at our second plan tier, Reliant Care 1.

Physician Services offer three Primary Care Visits per year, 

with a twenty-five dollar Co-pay and a one hundred fifty dollar maximum per visit. 

Hospitalization benefits provide one thousand dollars per day, 

with a five thousand dollar yearly maximum. 

Telemedicine services have No Consult Fee and No Maximum.

---- Plan Tier 2 (Two of Two) ----

Continuing with our second plan tier.

Advocacy includes the Hospital Bill Reducer. 

Limitations include a thirty-day waiting period for sickness benefits, 

and an in-network provider requirement.

---- Plan Tier 3 (One of Two) ----

Let's explore our third plan tier, Reliant Care 2.

Physician Services offer four Primary Care Visits per year, 

with a twenty-five dollar Co-pay and a one hundred fifty dollar maximum per visit. 

Hospitalization benefits provide one thousand dollars per day, 

with a ten thousand dollar yearly maximum. 

Telemedicine services have No Consult Fee and No Maximum.

---- Plan Tier 3 (Two of Two) ----

Continuing with our third plan tier.

Prescriptions include a Generic zero dollar Co-pay, 

and a Preferred Generic five dollar Co-pay. 

Limitations include a thirty-day waiting period for sickness benefits, 

and an in-network provider requirement.

---- Plan Tier 4 (One of Two) ----

Now, let's examine our fourth plan tier, Reliant Care 3.

Physician Services offer four Primary Care Visits per year, 

with a twenty-five dollar Co-pay and a one hundred fifty dollar maximum per visit. 

Hospitalization benefits provide one thousand dollars per day, 

with a fifteen thousand dollar yearly maximum. 

Telemedicine services have No Consult Fee and No Maximum.

---- Plan Tier 4 (Two of Two) ----

Continuing with our fourth plan tier.

Prescriptions include a Generic zero dollar Co-pay, 

and a Preferred Generic five dollar Co-pay. 

Limitations include a thirty-day waiting period for sickness benefits, 

and an in-network provider requirement.

---- Plan Tier 5 (One of Two) ----

Let's look at our fifth plan tier, Reliant Care 4.

Physician Services offer four Primary Care Visits per year, 

with a fifty dollar Co-pay and a one hundred fifty dollar maximum per visit. 

Hospitalization benefits provide one thousand dollars per day, 

with a ten thousand dollar yearly maximum. 

Surgery benefits offer one thousand dollars per year, 

with a two thousand dollar yearly maximum.

---- Plan Tier 5 (Two of Two) ----

Continuing with our fifth plan tier.

Telemedicine services have No Consult Fee and No Maximum. 

Limitations include a thirty-day waiting period for sickness benefits, 

and an in-network provider requirement.

---- Plan Tier 6 (One of Two) ----

Finally, let's explore our sixth plan tier, Reliant Care 5.

Physician Services offer five Primary Care Visits per year, 

with a fifty dollar Co-pay and a one hundred fifty dollar maximum per visit. 

Hospitalization benefits provide one thousand five hundred dollars per day, 

with a fifteen thousand dollar yearly maximum. 

Surgery benefits offer one thousand five hundred dollars per year, 

with a four thousand five hundred dollar yearly maximum.

---- Plan Tier 6 (Two of Two) ----

Continuing with our sixth plan tier.

Telemedicine services have No Consult Fee and No Maximum. 

Limitations include a thirty-day waiting period for sickness benefits, 

and an in-network provider requirement.

---- Comparing Plan Tiers ----

Let's compare the different tiers available.

The Wellness plan offers one Primary Care Visit per year, 

while Care 1 offers three, Care 2 and Care 3 offer four, 

Care 4 offers four, and Care 5 offers five visits per year. 

Hospitalization benefits range from one thousand dollars per day in Care 1 to one thousand five hundred dollars per day in Care 5. 

All plans include Telemedicine services with no consult fee.

---- Definitions and Limitations ----

Let's review important definitions and limitations.

Exclusions include Pre-existing Conditions, 

Waiting Periods, and Prescription Limitations. 

Specific Limitations include Specialty Drugs Excluded, 

and an in-network provider requirement.

---- Key Takeaways and Reminders ----

Here are the key points to remember.

There is Flexibility in plan options, 

with a balance between Cost and Coverage. 

Enrollment Support is available, 

and in-network providers are required.

---- Closing ----

Thank you for your time today. We hope this information helps you assist members in making informed decisions about their health coverage. Continue to be great!
